Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Structural Determinants of Permeation and Nucleation at a Self-Assembled Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this research program, with support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sunghee Lee of Iona College and her undergraduate students gain greater fundamental understanding of how living cells maintain their water balance - a property that is essential to life. They use nature-inspired techniques to create tailor-made particles - these particles are cell-sized water droplets which are used as models for natural cellular systems. A large number of undergraduate students are engaged in this research and many of these students publish peer-reviewed manuscripts. Diverse outreach seminars and science symposia involving high school students and teachers are conducted to inspire and encourage the next generation of STEM educators. Professor Lee reaches out to underrepresented groups in particular. In addition to understanding the water balance in living cells, the research could also have industrial applications in the design of reverse osmosis systems used to purify water.

This project focuses on understanding how supramolecular aggregates assembled at liquid-liquid interfaces (including surfactant bilayers) mediate the passage of small molecules and direct biomineralization. Systematic studies determine the effect of bilayer-incorporated materials (e.g., nanomaterials) upon the characteristics of water transport through the droplet interface bilayer (DIB). Experimental activities primarily focus on acquisition of water permeability parameters for osmotic flow in conjunction with the determination of electrical properties, and compositional studies via Raman quantification. Experimental strategies provide insight into how bilayered supramolecular assemblies promote the crystallization of important targets (biominerals and proteins), through nucleation studies of biomineral formation. Biomineralization is the process by which living organisms produce minerals that are often used to harden or stiffen existing tissues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF support has enabled us to establish a balanced combination of high-quality research at the confluence of surface chemistry and materials science, with research training of a large number of underrepresented students, at an undergraduate institution. The ability to determine the extent of small-molecule permeation, especially water molecules, has implications for enhanced human health in areas of organism homeostasis as well as retention and elimination of water and waste. In this field, we contributed studies that have systematically elaborated a highly configurable model membrane,  the droplet interface bilayer (DIB), for water permeability investigations. Specifically we investigated the effect of small crystallizable intercalants on the mechanism of water transport through amphiphilic bilayers, and engineered conditions to selectively self-assemble molecules within the bilayer environment. Our biomimetic semipermeable membrane system can assist in the design and manufacture of highly selective reverse osmosis systems, applicable to critical desalination projects for clean water to attend to a global crisis of water scarcity. Further, we have discovered that specific interaction of cholesterol with lipid components of model cell membranes exhibits a dramatic sensitivity to structural variations of lipidic acyl chains, leading to improved molecular level knowledge of cholesterol's role in the lipid bilayer. The resultant enhanced understanding of supramolecular self-assemblies at micron-sized liquid-liquid interfaces has significant implications in science, technology, and society. Materials science is moving towards the production of self-replicating and self-repairing systems, which will likely rely on understanding and controlling the dynamics of self-assembly. Additionally, biosensors, diagnostics, and drug screening platforms are all being developed based on lipid assemblies. Drug delivery systems benefit from self-assembled particles (e.g., liposomes, vesicles) with selectable properties. Enhanced insight into how lipidic surfactants assemble and pack will foster advances in biomimetics, soft matter, functional materials, and biological processes, at a fundamental level. Our research findings have been disseminated to communities of interest via local, regional, national and international professional conferences and peer-reviewed publications with undergraduate co-authors. A total of 6 peer-reviewed publications have been made with 15 undergraduate student as co-authors. A total of 139 presentations have been made by the PI and her undergraduate students, among which 77 presentations are made at the national level (e.g. ACS National Meeting, and National Conference for Undergraduate Research). 

The research funded under this proposal has been conducted at Iona College, an undergraduate institution, with undergraduate students as main participants in all aspects. The NSF support has allowed the PI to provide research training and professional development opportunities for 41 undergraduates (26 women and 15 males) and 5 high school students. The PI has established a rigorous plan for initiation and training of her students that has resulted in the ability to effectively manage a large group. Through a well-structured rigorous research program, students learn team cooperation, critical reasoning, problem solving, and planning skills.  Another significant aspect of the PI's research is the interdisciplinary nature of the project, that has catalyzed interdepartmental collaboration, as well as enabled students to gain a broad view of chemical research that will enhance their success as emerging professionals. Of equally significant value to students is the opportunity for undergraduates to engage in a cutting-edge collaborative relationship to develop a globally competitive STEM workforce. During the NSF grant period, 24 research students have graduated (17 female and 7 male) and among those graduates, 6 students advanced to PhD in STEM, 7 students are enrolled at or applying to MD program, 2 students are in MS programs and 9 students are employed full-time. The PI serves as the faculty coordinator for Iona STEP (Science and Technology Entry Program) and CSTEP, programs to encourage STEM careers for underrepresented students in grades 7-12 and college,  and has continued her outreach initiatives to increase recruitment of underrepresented groups to STEM through a close collaborative partnership with minority serving local high schools. The high-quality, engaged learning experience in research and education enabled production of an even greater number of undergraduates from underrepresented groups pursuing advanced degrees in STEM.
